elements.content: Six new coordination polymers, {[Zn2(DPT)2(btc)(Hbtc)]·2H2O} n (1), {[Cd(DPT)(Hbtc)(H2O)]·4H2O} n (2), {[Co(DPT)(Hbtc)]·1/2DPT} n (3), {[Zn(DPT)(oba)]·11H2O} n (4), {[Co2(DPT)2(oba)2]·DMF·3H2O} n (5), and {[Zn4(DPT)2(bdc)4(H2O)2]·2H2O·DMA} n (6), have been obtained from the self-assembly of the heterocycle ligand DPT with different metal salts, in the presence of coligands (DPT = 2,5-dipyridine-thiophene, H3btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, H2oba = 4,4′-oxybis(benzoate), H2bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide, DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide). Their structures have been characterized by single crystal X-ray analysis. Compounds 1–3 are 2D motifs, of which 1 and 2 are joined via H-bond bridges to give 3D supramolecular architectures. Complex 4 is a 2D network constructed from left- and right-handed helical chains. Complex 5 has a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D pcu framework. Complex 6 features a polycatened structure, which can be parallel/parallel catenated with two other equivalent bilayer ones to form a 2D → 3D framework. The photoluminescence properties of the compounds 1, 2, 4, and 6 have been examined in solid states at room temperature, and they have been found to exhibit yellow photoluminescence. In addition, the UV–visible spectra are also depicted in detail.

Complex 6 features a polycatened structure, which can be parallel/parallel catenated with two other equivalent bilayer ones to form a 2D → 3D framework. The photoluminescence properties of the compounds 1, 2, 4, and 6 have been examined in solid states at room temperature, and they have been found to exhibit yellow photoluminescence. In addition, the UV-visible spectra are also depicted in detail.

The photoluminescence properties of the d10 compounds have been examined, and they exhibit yellow photoluminescence. In addition, the UV−visible spectra are also depicted in detail.

elements.content: Much effort has been made toward the rapidly expanding field of crystal engineering of two- (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers due to their structural and topological diversities as well as their potential applications as functional materials. The main strategy used in this area is predetermined building materials. In a previous report, conjugated organic polymers such as thiophenes are natural semiconductors with tunable band gaps. Fujita and co-workers have reported the self-assembly of giant M24L48 coordination spheres from 24 palladium ions (M) and 48 curved bridging ligands with a thiophene group (L). Chung and co-workers have discovered that the bent ligand (2,5-bis(4-pyridylethynyl)thiophene) with a unusual flexibility can act a linear ligand by a conformational change. On the basis of the above and other research, we choose thiophene-2,5-dipyridine (DPT) as a linker to connect metal ions to get hybrid materials. The lone pair of electrons of the S atom can be more easily delocalized within the thiophene ring, and the ligand may display good charge-transfer ability. Structurally, DPT can be seen as a rigid “V-shaped” rigid organic ligand. Compared to a flexible ligand with conformational freedom, the rigid ligands are inclined to retain their geometry.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Much effort has been made toward the rapidly expanding field of crystal engineering of two- (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers due to their structural and topological diversities as well as their potential applications as functional materials. The main strategy used in this area is predetermined building materials. In a previous report, conjugated organic polymers such as thiophenes are natural semiconductors with tunable band gaps. Fujita and co-workers have reported the self-assembly of giant M24L48 coordination spheres from 24 palladium ions (M) and 48 curved bridging ligands with a thiophene group (L). Chung and co-workers have discovered that the bent ligand (2,5-bis(4-pyridylethynyl)thiophene) with a unusual flexibility can act a linear ligand by a conformational change. On the basis of the above and other research, we choose thiophene-2,5-dipyridine (DPT) as a linker to connect metal ions to get hybrid materials. The lone pair of electrons of the S atom can be more easily delocalized within the thiophene ring, and the ligand may display good charge-transfer ability. Structurally, DPT can be seen as a rigid "V-shaped" rigid organic ligand. Compared to a flexible ligand with conformational freedom, the rigid ligands are inclined to retain their geometry.

elements.content: Polycarboxylates are often employed as bridging ligands to construct coordination polymers because of their versatile coordination modes and their ability to act as H-bond acceptors and donors. In this paper, we synthesize six new metal–organic complexes based on DPT ligand and another three coligands, that is, {[Zn2(DPT)2(btc)(Hbtc)]·2H2O} n (1), {[Cd(DPT)(Hbtc)(H2O)]·4H2O} n (2), {[Co(DPT)(Hbtc)]·1/2DPT} n (3), {[Zn(DPT)(oba)]·11H2O} n (4), {[Co2(DPT)2(oba)2]·DMF·3H2O} n (5), and {[Zn4(DPT)2(bdc)4(H2O)2]·2H2O·DMA} n (6). In addition, we also describe the details of their characterizations and properties.

elements.content: All chemicals and solvents except DPT ligand were of reagent-grade quality from commercial sources and were used without further purification. The DPT ligand was synthesized in a single step from pyridine-4-boronic acid and the corresponding 2,5-dihalothiophenes in reasonable yields by using the Suzuki–Miyaura procedure. The IR absorption spectra of these complexes were recorded in the range 400–4000 cm–1 by means of a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets. Element analyses (C, H, N) were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer model 240C analyzer. PXRD measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (0.15418 nm), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. Luminescent spectra were recorded with a SHIMAZU VF-320 X-ray fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature (25 °C). Solid-state UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were obtained at room temperature using a Shimadzu UV-3600 double monochromator spectrophotometer, and BaSO4 was used as a 100% reflectance standard for all materials. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer Pyris 1 TGA from room temperature to 750 °C with a heating rate of 20 K·min–1 under N2 atmosphere.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals and solvents except DPT ligand were of reagent-grade quality from commercial sources and were used without further purification. The DPT ligand was synthesized in a single step from pyridine-4-boronic acid and the corresponding 2,5-dihalothiophenes in reasonable yields by using the Suzuki-Miyaura procedure. The IR absorption spectra of these complexes were recorded in the range 400-4000 cm-1 by means of a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets. Element analyses (C, H, N) were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer model 240C analyzer. PXRD measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (0.15418 nm), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. Luminescent spectra were recorded with a SHIMAZU VF-320 X-ray fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature (25 °C). Solid-state UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra were obtained at room temperature using a Shimadzu UV-3600 double monochromator spectrophotometer, and BaSO4 was used as a 100% reflectance standard for all materials. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer Pyris 1 TGA from room temperature to 750 °C with a heating rate of 20 K⋅min-1 under N2 atmosphere.

elements.content: Single crystals of 1–6 were prepared by the methods described in the synthetic procedure. The crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray analyses. Data collections were performed using a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation with an φ–ω mode (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved with direct methods using the SHELXTL program and refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures. In the X-ray crystal structure analysis, some residual electron densities in compounds 2–6 were observed within the pores, and assignment to a specific molecule cannot be made. They were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. Crystallographic data and experimental details for these complexes are given in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1.

Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystals of 1-6 were prepared by the methods described in the synthetic procedure. The crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray analyses. Data collections were performed using a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation with an φ-ω mode (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved with direct methods using the SHELXTL program and refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures. In the X-ray crystal structure analysis, some residual electron densities in compounds 2-6 were observed within the pores, and assignment to a specific molecule cannot be made. They were removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. Crystallographic data and experimental details for these complexes are given in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two crystallographically independent Zn2+ ions, two DPT ligands, one btc anion, one partly deprotonated Hbtc, and two lattice water molecules. Both the DPT ligands show a terminal coordination mode. In the btc, two carboxylate groups exhibit monodentate connectivity and another shows a bimonodentate mode, while, in the Hbtc, one carboxylate exhibits monodentate connectivity and the other exhibits bimonodentate connectivity, as shown in Figure a. Of the two Zn cations, Zn1 is tetrahedrally coordinated by three oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups and one nitrogen atom from DPT. Zn2 prefers a square-pyramidal geometry, with a DPT molecule coordinated to the Zn2 center, to form Zn paddle-wheel second building units (SBUs), and the Zn–Zn distance is approximately 3.017. The Zn–O bond lengths are in the range 1.943(2)–2.092(2) Å, and the Zn–N bond lengths are 2.020(2) Å and 2.035(2) Å, which are all similar to those values found in other complexes. The Hbtc anion and btc alternately connect Zn centers to furnish a 2D framework with the dangling arms, as depicted in Figure b. Because the carboxylate groups are partly deprotonated and the framework has two lattice water molecules, three types of hydrogen bonds can be found in this structure, which range from what is considered strong, 2.582(3)Å, to those considered weak, 2.856(4) Å (Table ). These layers are held together by different types of hydrogen bonding interactions involving lattice water and a carboxylate unit in the structure to yield a 3-D solid and generate another Zn2(CO2)4(H2O)2 SBU (Figure c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of the Crystal Structure of {[Zn2(DPT)2(btc)(Hbtc)]⋅2H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two crystallographically independent Zn2+ ions, two DPT ligands, one btc anion, one partly deprotonated Hbtc, and two lattice water molecules. Both the DPT ligands show a terminal coordination mode. In the btc, two carboxylate groups exhibit monodentate connectivity and another shows a bimonodentate mode, while, in the Hbtc, one carboxylate exhibits monodentate connectivity and the other exhibits bimonodentate connectivity, as shown in Figure a. Of the two Zn cations, Zn1 is tetrahedrally coordinated by three oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups and one nitrogen atom from DPT. Zn2 prefers a square-pyramidal geometry, with a DPT molecule coordinated to the Zn2 center, to form Zn paddle-wheel second building units (SBUs), and the Zn-Zn distance is approximately 3.017. The Zn-O bond lengths are in the range 1.943(2)-2.092(2) Å, and the Zn-N bond lengths are 2.020(2) Å and 2.035(2) Å, which are all similar to those values found in other complexes. The Hbtc anion and btc alternately connect Zn centers to furnish a 2D framework with the dangling arms, as depicted in Figure b. Because the carboxylate groups are partly deprotonated and the framework has two lattice water molecules, three types of hydrogen bonds can be found in this structure, which range from what is considered strong, 2.582(3)Å, to those considered weak, 2.856(4) Å (Table ). These layers are held together by different types of hydrogen bonding interactions involving lattice water and a carboxylate unit in the structure to yield a 3-D solid and generate another Zn2(CO2)4(H2O)2 SBU (Figure c).

elements.content: To better understand the nature of this intricate supramolecular framework, a TOPOS analysis is provided by the software TOPOS4.0. The Zn paddle-wheel SBUs and the btc ligands can be regarded as 4-connected, 3-connected nodes, respectively. The Zn2(CO2)4(H2O)2 SBUs act as a 8-connected node. Therefore, the whole structure can thus be represented as a 3,4,8-c 3-nodal net.

elements.content: Complex 2 is a two-dimensional (2D) framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Cd cation, one DPT ligand, one Hbtc ligand, one coordinated water molecule, and one lattice water molecule. Cd is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different Hbtc ligands, one water molecule, and one N atom from DPT (Figure a). In this structure, the Hbtc ligands adopt monodentate connectivity and the bidentate chelating mode, respectively. Both the rigid carboxylate ligands and the DPT act as bidentate ligands combined with four Cd atoms to form a 44 2D sheet, as shown in Figure b. Similar to the case of 1, there are six types of intramolecular hydrogen bonds between water and carboxylic oxygen atoms or nitrogen atoms (Table ). When the hydrogen bonds are considered, the adjacent layers are connected by these hydrogen bonds into a 3D network, as depicted Figure c. Similar to the case of compound 1, The hydrogen bonds connect the uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen and lattice water molecule to generate Cd2(CO2)4(H2O)2 SBUs.

Description of the Crystal Structure of {[Cd(DPT)(Hbtc)(H2O)]⋅4H2O} n  (2)

Complex 2 is a two-dimensional (2D) framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one Cd cation, one DPT ligand, one Hbtc ligand, one coordinated water molecule, and one lattice water molecule. Cd is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different Hbtc ligands, one water molecule, and one N atom from DPT (Figure a). In this structure, the Hbtc ligands adopt monodentate connectivity and the bidentate chelating mode, respectively. Both the rigid carboxylate ligands and the DPT act as bidentate ligands combined with four Cd atoms to form a 44 2D sheet, as shown in Figure b. Similar to the case of 1, there are six types of intramolecular hydrogen bonds between water and carboxylic oxygen atoms or nitrogen atoms (Table ). When the hydrogen bonds are considered, the adjacent layers are connected by these hydrogen bonds into a 3D network, as depicted Figure c. Similar to the case of compound 1, The hydrogen bonds connect the uncoordinated carboxyl oxygen and lattice water molecule to generate Cd2(CO2)4(H2O)2 SBUs.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis exhibits that 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and consists of one Co cation, one DPT, and one Hbtc ligand (Figure b). The Hbtc ligands adopt two types of coordination modes, containing a syn–syn bridging mode and a bidentate-chelating mode. The Co center is octahedrally coordinated by four oxygen atoms belonging to three Hbtc ligands and two nitrogen atoms from DPT ligands, with the Co–O distances ranging from 2.018(3) Å to 2.224(3) Å and Co–N distances ranging from 2.150(3) Å to 2.157(3) Å. As shown in Figure b, two carboxylate groups of the Hbtc ligand have two coordination modes. One bidentately bridges two Co atoms in a syn–syn fashion, and the other chelates one Co atom, which generates a [Co2(CO2)4] eight-membered ring. Each [Co2(CO2)4] unit binds to two adjacent units to form a 1D chain by bridging Hbtc ligands. Finally, the DPT ligands join all 1D chains into a bilayer 2D sheet.

elements.content: X-ray analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 4 consists of one crystallographically independent Zn(II) cation, one DPT ligand, and one oba ligand. As shown in Figure a, both the carboxylate groups adopt the same monodentate coordination mode. The Zn center is four-coordinated by two oxygen atoms belonging to two oba ligands and two nitrogen atoms from DPT ligands with the Zn–O distances ranging from 1.958(3) Å to 1.960(3) Å and the Zn–N distances ranging from 2.025(3) Å to 2.068(3) Å. It is obvious that the DPT ligand is in a distorted configuration (Figure S7). The DPT ligands connected adjacent zinc atoms to form a 1D right-handed helix along the c-axis, as described in Figure b. When viewed along the a-axis, the left-handed chains are shown by DPT and oba alternately connecting to the Zn centers (Figure c). Because left-handed and right-handed helical chains coexist in the crystal structure, the whole crystal is racemic and does not exhibit chirality.

elements.content: The crystal structure determination reveals that compound 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of P21/c. The asymmetric unit contains two Co(II) cations, two DPT ligands, and two oba ligands (Figure a). The two oba ligands adopt different coordination modes. The carboxylate groups of one oba adopt monodentate and bis-monodentate coordination modes, whereas, in the other oba ligand, the carboxylate groups adopt the bis-monodentate coordination mode to bridge two Co centers and the chelating coordination mode to one Co center, respectively. As shown in Figure b, two Co(II) cations are bridged by two carboxylate groups, forming an eight-membered [Co2(CO2)4] ring. The Co–Co distance across the binuclear unit is 3.732 Å. Four oba ligands connect four [Co2(CO2)4] units to form a M4L4 ring, and each [Co2(CO2)4] unit binds to four adjacent units to form an undulating 2D network with 44 topology (Figure b). Parallel 2D layers are connected by the DPT ligands to form a 3D coordination polymer network (Figure c). The potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of two independent equivalent frameworks, generating a 3-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure d). The interpenetration can be classified as type Class Ia, Z = 3 (Zt = 3; Zn = 1) (the identical interpenetrated nets are generated by translation, and the translating vector is [0,0,1] (13.04 Å). From a topological perspective, the [Co2(CO2)4] unit acts as a 6-connected node, and complex 5 represents the {412·63} α-Po pcu topology by using DPT and oba ligands as linkers.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction analysis shows that complex 6 features an (2D + 2D → 3D) parallel polycatenated entanglement. The asymmetry unit of 6 contains four independent Zn atoms. Zn2 has a tetrahedral geometry and is coordinated by three O atoms from three bdc ligands and one N atom from DPT ligand. Zn1, Zn3, and Zn4 are square-pyramidal geometries. There are four independent bdc ligands in compound 6 that show three linking modes (Figure S8): the two bdc ligands connect four Zn atoms by each carboxylate group and bidentately bridge two Zn atomsone bdc ligand shows both monodentate modes, another exhibits the monodentate mode, and another the bidentate chelating mode. Each two-Zn unit is bridged by two carboxylate groups, with the Zn···Zn distances being 3.747 Å and 3.813 Å, respectively. One dinuclear Zn unit is bound by four bdc ligands and two parallel DPT ligands. Four bdc ligands connect four dinuclear Zn units to generate a (4,4) net, and the DPT ligands locate in the same side, linking to a second sheet to give a bilayer motif (Figure b). The voids are enough large so that they can be filled by other nets. Each one is catenated by two parallel adjacent identical motifs. Therefore, the whole structure is a polycatenated entanglement of 2D architecture (Figure c).

elements.content: As can be seen in the UV–vis absorbance spectra (Figure S9a), the H3btc and the DPT show intense absorption peaks in the UV range at 250–300 nm and 250–420 nm, respectively, which can both be ascribed to π–π* transitions of the ligands. We observe peaks at 450–570 nm for compound 3 and 450–600 nm for compound 5, which arise from the d–d electronic transitions. To explore the semiconductivity, the diffuse reflectivity is transformed into absorbance using the Kubelka–Munk function. As shown in Figure S9b of the , the band gap of DPT is approximately 2.47 eV, which exhibits the nature of semiconductivity. The absorption band sites at 1.63 eV and 2.0 eV for 3 and at 1.47 eV and 2.56 eV for 5, respectively, are estimated to be greater than those of the semiconductor silicon material, with a band gap of 1.1 eV.
elements.clean_text:
UV-Visible Spectra

As can be seen in the UV-vis absorbance spectra (Figure S9a), the H3btc and the DPT show intense absorption peaks in the UV range at 250-300 nm and 250-420 nm, respectively, which can both be ascribed to π-π* transitions of the ligands. We observe peaks at 450-570 nm for compound 3 and 450-600 nm for compound 5, which arise from the d-d electronic transitions. To explore the semiconductivity, the diffuse reflectivity is transformed into absorbance using the Kubelka-Munk function. As shown in Figure S9b of the , the band gap of DPT is approximately 2.47 eV, which exhibits the nature of semiconductivity. The absorption band sites at 1.63 eV and 2.0 eV for 3 and at 1.47 eV and 2.56 eV for 5, respectively, are estimated to be greater than those of the semiconductor silicon material, with a band gap of 1.1 eV.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescence of complexes 1, 2, 4, and 6, and of the free ligand DPT, H2bdc, and H3btc, are investigated at room temperature, as shown in Figure S10 and Table S2 of the . There is no obvious emission observed for the H2oba ligand under the same experimental conditions. These compounds, except H2bdc and H3btc ligands, exhibit strong yellow emission with a broad band in the range 450–570 nm. Compared with the emission spectra of the DPT (λem = 478 nm), these compounds are all red-shifted. The emission spectra of complexes 1 and 2 show that the emission peaks center at 517, 532 nm. The emission peaks of complex 4 and complex 6 are red-shifted 14 and 37 nm, respectively. The origin of the broad and red-shifted emission bands may be attributed to the contribution of ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The differences in the band positions of these coordination polymers might be related to the differences in the metal centers and coordination environments or the degree of π electron overlap of the organic linkers in these structures. The significantly stronger fluorescence compared with ligands may be ascribed to the coordination effect, which effectively reduces the nonradiative loss of energy by increasing the rigidity of the ligand. Furthermore, the emission decay lifetimes of these compounds were monitored and the curves are best fitted by biexponentials in solid. The emission decay lifetimes are τ1 = 1.02 μs, τ2 = 9.91 μs (χ2 = 1.291, Figure S11 of the ) for DPT ligand, τ1 = 1.42 μs, τ2 = 13.49 μs (χ2 = 1.282, Figure S12) for compound 1, τ1 = 1.95 μs, τ2 = 16.52 μs (χ2 = 1.338, Figure S13) for compound 2, τ1 = 1.12 μs, τ2 = 11.48 μs (χ2 = 1.220, Figure S14) for compound 4, and τ1 = 1.69 μs, τ2 = 12.72 μs (χ2 = 1.345, Figure S15) for compound 6.

The origin of the broad and red-shifted emission bands may be attributed to the contribution of ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The differences in the band positions of these coordination polymers might be related to the differences in the metal centers and coordination environments or the degree of π electron overlap of the organic linkers in these structures. The significantly stronger fluorescence compared with ligands may be ascribed to the coordination effect, which effectively reduces the nonradiative loss of energy by increasing the rigidity of the ligand. Furthermore, the emission decay lifetimes of these compounds were monitored and the curves are best fitted by biexponentials in solid. The emission decay lifetimes are τ1 = 1.02 μs, τ2 = 9.91 μs (χ2 = 1.291, Figure S11 of the ) for DPT ligand, τ1 = 1.42 μs, τ2 = 13.49 μs (χ2 = 1.282, Figure S12) for compound 1, τ1 = 1.95 μs, τ2 = 16.52 μs (χ2 = 1.338, Figure S13) for compound 2, τ1 = 1.12 μs, τ2 = 11.48 μs (χ2 = 1.220, Figure S14) for compound 4, and τ1 = 1.69 μs, τ2 = 12.72 μs (χ2 = 1.345, Figure S15) for compound 6.

elements.content: To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TG analyses were carried out (Figure S16 of the ). For compound 1, a rapid weight loss is observed from 40 to 105 °C which is ascribed to the loss of two lattice water molecules, with a weight loss of 3.86% (calcd 3.4%); then the decomposition of complex 1 starts. The obvious weight loss of 12.61% for compound 2 from 70 to 250 °C corresponds to the loss of four lattice waters and one coordinated water molecule (calcd 13.24%); then the organic ligands begin to decompose. The TGA curve of 3 shows that there is a rapid weight loss of approximately 19.41% between 20 and 215 °C, corresponding to the loss of half of a free DPT molecule (calcd 19.07%). Then the decomposition of the ligands begins. The TGA study of compound 4 shows a weight loss of 26.41% (calcd 26.12%) from 50 to 120 °C, suggesting that the solvent H2O molecule is removed. Above 310 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed, attributed to the decomposition of the coordination framework. For complex 5, a weight loss is observed from 30 to 300 °C which is attributed to the loss of the three lattice waters and one DMF molecule, with a weight loss of 10.85% (calcd 10.29%); then the ligands are removed from the complex. The TGA curve of 6 indicates that there is an initial weight loss of approximately 7.57% between 25 and 230 °C, corresponding to the loss of the guests (7.92% calcd for two H2O and one DMA molecule per unit formula). Then two coordinated water molecules are gradually removed in the temperature range 230–380 °C (calcd 10.24; found 10.00%); finally, the decomposition of the ligands begins. The purities of polymers 1–6 are confirmed by X-ray power diffraction analyses, in which the experimental spectra of polymers 1–6 are almost consistent with their simulated spectra (Figures S17–S22).

Thermogravimetric Analyses and X-ray Powder Diffraction

To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TG analyses were carried out (Figure S16 of the ). For compound 1, a rapid weight loss is observed from 40 to 105 °C which is ascribed to the loss of two lattice water molecules, with a weight loss of 3.86% (calcd 3.4%); then the decomposition of complex 1 starts. The obvious weight loss of 12.61% for compound 2 from 70 to 250 °C corresponds to the loss of four lattice waters and one coordinated water molecule (calcd 13.24%); then the organic ligands begin to decompose. The TGA curve of 3 shows that there is a rapid weight loss of approximately 19.41% between 20 and 215 °C, corresponding to the loss of half of a free DPT molecule (calcd 19.07%). Then the decomposition of the ligands begins. The TGA study of compound 4 shows a weight loss of 26.41% (calcd 26.12%) from 50 to 120 °C, suggesting that the solvent H2O molecule is removed. Above 310 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed, attributed to the decomposition of the coordination framework. For complex 5, a weight loss is observed from 30 to 300 °C which is attributed to the loss of the three lattice waters and one DMF molecule, with a weight loss of 10.85% (calcd 10.29%); then the ligands are removed from the complex. The TGA curve of 6 indicates that there is an initial weight loss of approximately 7.57% between 25 and 230 °C, corresponding to the loss of the guests (7.92% calcd for two H2O and one DMA molecule per unit formula). Then two coordinated water molecules are gradually removed in the temperature range 230-380 °C (calcd 10.24; found 10.00%); finally, the decomposition of the ligands begins. The purities of polymers 1-6 are confirmed by X-ray power diffraction analyses, in which the experimental spectra of polymers 1-6 are almost consistent with their simulated spectra (Figures S17-S22).

elements.content: In summary, we successfully synthesized six coordination polymers, which were constructed from DPT in the presence of coligands under similar hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1–3 are all 2D motifs, while 1 and 2 are joined via H-bond bridges to give different 3D supramolecular architectures. The structural difference of these compouds may be attributed to the different bridging fashions of the H3btc ligand and the versatility of the metal coordination geometry. In addition, compound 4 is a 2D structure with left-handed and right-handed helix chains. When changing the Zn(II) to Co(II) cation, a 3-fold interpenetrated pcu framework 5 is obtained. The coordination modes of the metal centers play a vital important role in the formation of the different structures. Compound 6 is also a 3D supermolecule by a parallel polycatenated interaction. Changing the proportion of raw materials and solvents, we will get a three-dimensional compound 5 compared with 2D bilayer 6. Compounds 1, 2, 4, and 6 exhibit yellow luminescence emissions. The optical absorption spectra of 3 and 5 indicate the nature of semiconductivity. Work is also underway to study that more MOFs with fascinating structures and interesting potential properties based on the semiconducting materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we successfully synthesized six coordination polymers, which were constructed from DPT in the presence of coligands under similar hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1-3 are all 2D motifs, while 1 and 2 are joined via H-bond bridges to give different 3D supramolecular architectures. The structural difference of these compouds may be attributed to the different bridging fashions of the H3btc ligand and the versatility of the metal coordination geometry. In addition, compound 4 is a 2D structure with left-handed and right-handed helix chains. When changing the Zn(II) to Co(II) cation, a 3-fold interpenetrated pcu framework 5 is obtained. The coordination modes of the metal centers play a vital important role in the formation of the different structures. Compound 6 is also a 3D supermolecule by a parallel polycatenated interaction. Changing the proportion of raw materials and solvents, we will get a three-dimensional compound 5 compared with 2D bilayer 6. Compounds 1, 2, 4, and 6 exhibit yellow luminescence emissions. The optical absorption spectra of 3 and 5 indicate the nature of semiconductivity. Work is also underway to study that more MOFs with fascinating structures and interesting potential properties based on the semiconducting materials.

A mixture of DMF/H2O containing the DPT (23.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3btc (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O/Cd(NO3)2·6H2O/Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg/30.1 mg/29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) was placed in a Teflon vessel within the autoclave. The vessel was heated at 90 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature. Block crystals were obtained. Yields of the reaction were ca. 60% (127.0 mg), 55% (71.1 mg), 65% (32.8 mg) based on DPT ligand. Elemental analysis: Calcd for C92H61N8O28S4Zn4 (1): C, 52.21; H, 2.91; N, 5.29. Synthesis of Complexes <bold>4</bold> and <bold>5</bold>

A mixture of DMF/H2O containing the DPT (23.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2oba (25.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O/Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg/29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) was mixed in a Teflon vessel within the autoclave. The vessel was heated at 90 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature. Block crystals were obtained. Yields of the reaction were ca. 60% (45.5 mg), 55% (67.9 mg) based on DPT ligand. Elemental analysis: Calcd for C28H40N2SZnO16 (4): C, 44.36; H, 5.32; N, 3.70. Found: C, 44.89; H, 4.96; N, 3.95. Calcd for C59H49N5S2Co2O14 (5): C, 57.42; H, 4.00; N, 5.67. cln_elements.content:
The solid-state luminescence of complexes 1, 2, 4, and 6, and of the free ligand DPT, H2bdc, and H3btc, are investigated at room temperature, as shown in Figure S10 and Table S2 of the . There is no obvious emission observed for the H2oba ligand under the same experimental conditions. These compounds, except H2bdc and H3btc ligands, exhibit strong yellow emission with a broad band in the range 450–570 nm. Compared with the emission spectra of the DPT (λem = 478 nm), these compounds are all red-shifted. The emission spectra of complexes 1 and 2 show that the emission peaks center at 517, 532 nm. The emission peaks of complex 4 and complex 6 are red-shifted 14 and 37 nm, respectively. The origin of the broad and red-shifted emission bands may be attributed to the contribution of ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The differences in the band positions of these coordination polymers might be related to the differences in the metal centers and coordination environments or the degree of π electron overlap of the organic linkers in these structures. The significantly stronger fluorescence compared with ligands may be ascribed to the coordination effect, which effectively reduces the nonradiative loss of energy by increasing the rigidity of the ligand. Furthermore, the emission decay lifetimes of these compounds were monitored and the curves are best fitted by biexponentials in solid. The emission decay lifetimes are τ1 = 1.02 μs, τ2 = 9.91 μs (χ2 = 1.291, Figure S11 of the ) for DPT ligand, τ1 = 1.42 μs, τ2 = 13.49 μs (χ2 = 1.282, Figure S12) for compound 1, τ1 = 1.95 μs, τ2 = 16.52 μs (χ2 = 1.338, Figure S13) for compound 2, τ1 = 1.12 μs, τ2 = 11.48 μs (χ2 = 1.220, Figure S14) for compound 4, and τ1 = 1.69 μs, τ2 = 12.72 μs (χ2 = 1.345, Figure S15) for compound 6.

Thermogravimetric Analyses and X-ray Powder Diffraction

To examine the thermal stabilities of these compounds, TG analyses were carried out (Figure S16 of the ). For compound 1, a rapid weight loss is observed from 40 to 105 °C which is ascribed to the loss of two lattice water molecules, with a weight loss of 3.86% (calcd 3.4%); then the decomposition of complex 1 starts. The obvious weight loss of 12.61% for compound 2 from 70 to 250 °C corresponds to the loss of four lattice waters and one coordinated water molecule (calcd 13.24%); then the organic ligands begin to decompose. The TGA curve of 3 shows that there is a rapid weight loss of approximately 19.41% between 20 and 215 °C, corresponding to the loss of half of a free DPT molecule (calcd 19.07%). Then the decomposition of the ligands begins. The TGA study of compound 4 shows a weight loss of 26.41% (calcd 26.12%) from 50 to 120 °C, suggesting that the solvent H2O molecule is removed. Above 310 °C, a rapid weight loss is observed, attributed to the decomposition of the coordination framework. For complex 5, a weight loss is observed from 30 to 300 °C which is attributed to the loss of the three lattice waters and one DMF molecule, with a weight loss of 10.85% (calcd 10.29%); then the ligands are removed from the complex. The TGA curve of 6 indicates that there is an initial weight loss of approximately 7.57% between 25 and 230 °C, corresponding to the loss of the guests (7.92% calcd for two H2O and one DMA molecule per unit formula). Then two coordinated water molecules are gradually removed in the temperature range 230–380 °C (calcd 10.24; found 10.00%); finally, the decomposition of the ligands begins. The purities of polymers 1–6 are confirmed by X-ray power diffraction analyses, in which the experimental spectra of polymers 1–6 are almost consistent with their simulated spectra (Figures S17–S22).
